channel.name: A potential issue with the current fungible token standard

messages.content:
Guys, I have noticed a potentially significant issue in the current token standard contract code that requires attention. To ensure it receives proper visibility, I will share the link to the GitHub issue I have already posted below and look forward to hearing the community's perspectives on it.

With the default permission configuration, it may become impossible to ever upgrade the contract
https://github.com/MinaFoundation/mina-fungible-token/issues/112

embeds.title: The default permission setup might make it impossible to ever upgra...
embeds.description: The default permission settings of the current token standard contract are configured this way: mina-fungible-token/FungibleToken.ts Lines 73 to 77 in 7f2427a this.account.permissions.set({ ...Perm...

messages.content: Changed the channel name: A potential issue with the current fungible token standard
@Florian pinging here too for visibility
Seems very important
You can see Florian's comments on it at https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1302964466073341952
This seems different?
i will take a look in a bit! In the meanwhile, tagging @Philipp who worked on the token standard

Oh, so if I understand this correctly, this issue is basically an incompatibility of having `access` permission of `Proof` and `setVerificationKey` set to `impossibleDuringCurrentVersion`?

That’s a good find, thanks!

I think making changes to `access` (either to just effect tokens, as in the pre-MIP, or making an exception for changing the verification key after a protocol update) is a good way of fixing this.

On a related note, I want to change the rules about allowing updates of the verification key of the token contract. I’m not really satisfied with the `impossibleDuringCurrentVersion` solution: it allows both too much (arbitrary upgrades after an incompatible protocol change) and not enough (update to keep up with new versions of o1js).

I’m much happier with the solution that @DFST is using for the nfts: requiring sign of by multiple parties to allow a change of the verification key.
@Philipp this is unfortunately not enough
Even before hardfork you often need to use signatures
@Las Do you mean generally, or for the fungible tokens specifically?
In general.
access permission is borked
Needs to be reworked completely

Ah, ok. For the fungible tokens specifically, we wanted to limit the things the deployer could do after deployment as much as possible, so I would have been surprised if there were more things you could use the signature for.

The good news then is that at least for the fungible tokens, this will only become relevant after an incompatible protocol upgrade, and if we get agreement that the access permission needs to be reworked, that could be delivered before it becomes relevant for the tokens.
But the point remains that I really want to change the updatability of the token contract.

For the current token standard, as long as the access permission is set to Proof, we cannot upgrade the contract using signature authorization. If the setVerificationKey permission is also set to Proof, we can use the existing updateVerificationKey method defined in the contract to generate a proof for upgrading the contract. However, this method appears to allow anyone to upgrade the contract, as there is no access control in place.

Good point, thanks.
So, adding access control to that method, and then setting updateVerificationKey to proof would be necessary.

But doesn't fix the original problem raised -- that after an upgrade you couldn't change the verification key. Because the access/proof permission would prevent updating the vk, and the outdated vk would prevent proofs from working, it's a cycle
And the `impossibleDuringCurrentVersion` always switches to `signature` after an incompatible protocol change? There's no setting that will switch it to `proof` instead?
^^ this is something @Youtpout has asked me about as well.  Currently, that is correct.  How can we verify a proof if the version is not compatible?
Yep - switching it to proof wouldn't help

Would the short term fix for the token contract -- requiring a signature in the `updateVerificationKey()` method to make sure only the deployer calls it, and then setting the permission to change the verification key to `proof` work? Or would we end up requiring a signature and a proof again?
I don’t see how this would work
You can’t use proofs after hf
The real issue is that the access permission is fundamentally broken.
It conflates two very different kinds of access, and one of them isn’t very useful.
It should really only apply to permitting child account updates.
Should the hardfork be designed in a way to allow accepting before-hardfork proofs for the limited purpose of upgrading verification keys?
Not much easier than just not breaking compatibility I think.
Really people should just do the upgrade before hardfork.
There should be a way to specify two active vks instead of one
Then people can set the second one before the hf

@Philipp did you see Matthew's comment? (https://github.com/MinaFoundation/mina-fungible-token/issues/112#issuecomment-2526280000)

Good news, sounds like nothing has to be fixed in the token standad!

That is great news! What I still want to change is adding access management to the `updateVerificationKey` method, in order to enable making the contract upgradable before a breaking change to the protocol. That way, people can upgrade to keep up to date with fixes and improvements in o1js.
You can just do that yourself
Yes! I just created a pull request with that change, see https://github.com/MinaFoundation/mina-fungible-token/pull/113. @gregor @ymekuria, could you review that change please?

embeds.title: Build software better, together
embeds.description: GitHub is where people build software. More than 100 million people use GitHub to discover, fork, and contribute to over 420 million projects.

messages.content:
It is clearly a breaking change, and if we're speaking about breaking changes, I would also consider adding the `canTransfer()` method to make FungibleToken KYC/AML/Travel rule compliant, which can be important for exchanges and regulators.
Calling `canTransfer()` in the admin contract can be optional and regulated by a Bool flag in the FungibleToken state.

That would we a valuable addition, yes! And if we guard the call into `canTransfer()` by a flag in the contract state, then for tokens that do not use `canTransfer()`, transfers would not rely on having the code for the admin contract at all, right?
Yes, but we need to use conditional AccountUpdate or two methods for it - one with call to `canTransfer()` and one without, as currently conditional code execution is not supported in SmartContracts.
Include it now will break compatibility with current fungible token standard
Yes, but the PR above already breaks it, so it is a good time to think about what else should be included if we make breaking changes.
I'd like to merge this, but would be great to have a review first! @ymekuria @DFST @gregor if one of you could have a look at it, that would be great!
If I use a fungible token in one of my smartcontract, and the token owner upgrade the token code, my contrct will continue to work? do I need to update his verification key ?

Yes, you will need to use the updated code as well.
To elaborate: if you are calling a method of a contract from somewhere else (including from your own contract), you execute the code of that method off-chain, and are generating a proof that you’ve executed the code correctly. That proof is validated against the verification key that is stored on chain (in the account the contract has been deployed to). A change of the contract causes the verification key to change as well. So if you’re not using the same version of the code, then the proof will not be valid.

That’s the technical reason — the conceptual reason is that or should not work with the old code. If the contract is changed, then any invocation of the contract needs to use the same code. Otherwise, there would be no consistency, everyone could just use the contract they want to use.
Hey @Philipp don't have a lot of bandwidth these days, but I did a quick review of the contract changes
Awesome, thanks!
Ok, version `1.1.0` is now both on github and on npm!
Ok we need a stable verification key generation so in the futur, some protocol are not upgradable and depend from mina fungible token
Sorry, I’m not sure I understand that. Do you mean we should disallow updates of the contract?

@Philipp imagine you run a DEX where any token can be exchanged for any other token.  If all tokens use the FT standard, then they should all have the same VK and you only need one branch of logic to transfer any token.

If token admins are upgrading their VKs left and right, no DEX will be able to keep up with the combinations.
Maybe something in the middle will work where there are versions of the standard FT and zkApps can add support for 1+ versions.

Indeed, we’ll want to minimize the number of different versions that are in use at any point in time.
I think that this is an argument _for_ allowing upgrades: if you disallow updates, then a token launched today will always be on version 1 (and tied to a specific version of o1js). And with each new version, we will have tokens tied to another version of the token contract and o1js.
If we allow for updates, a DEX could establish a policy that only tokens with the latest version (or the latest and the one before that) can be traded.
Our pool are not upgradable for security reason, if the user upgrade his token so the pool will stop working
We need to implement upgradable mechanism so, but it adds complexity given the number of potential pools to manage

Is it possible to allow the TokenAdmin contract to authorize and decide whether to upgrade the pool? The security of a token is usually associated with the Token Owner. If the Token Owner decides to upgrade the token contract, we might as well centralize the authority to upgrade the pool in the hands of the Token Owner as well. For example, an authorization method could be defined in the TokenAdmin contract to handle this.

If you have a pool usdc/pepe, who can upgrade the pool pepe or usdc or the two admins ?

Also how you can deal with a dex who can have different verification key for each pool ?

The upgrade approach should be determined based on the specific implementation of the pool. In my opinion, a more efficient way would be to introduce a centralized contract to manage the upgrades of all pools. Only the TokenOwner of any token within a pool can initiate an upgrade request and execute the authorization process through the TokenAdmin contract. Additionally, this upgrade process would require approval via voting from the holders of the corresponding LP tokens for the pool.

Complex to integrate, also for pool with 2 tokens, if the 2 tokens didn't have same version it will be funny, the fungible token really need to have consistent verification key, I can understand in case of hardfork we need to manage it, but if at each o1js major version we have different verification key it can be really difficult to handle that and cause fragmentation
